thank you very much all for coming here today my name is Craig box I lead the
developer advocacy teams for kubernetes and Misty Oh on Google Cloud based in London so my job is traveling the world
and talking to people about the open-source projects that we've built our cloud products that were built on
top of them and getting feedback from people about what they like and what they would like to see changed and what
I want to talk about today is the ISTE o project and specifically why sto was so
compelling to customers that they would use it in production one month after we
released it as open source along with IBM we launched sto and we know of
customers who were using version zero point two so you have to be very brave to want to use something so young but it
must solve a real problem that people have and it's important to know what
those problems are so we can see if we can apply them to your business now the
most common use case for something like sto is when you're looking at moving a
monolithic application to micro services monolithic applications used to just be
the only way we would build software it was fantastic because we would write everything in one process and so we knew
that it all worked we compiled everything together you could call any function so some of
those modules they're just sort of call each other around in the circle but that's okay there are downsides to this you have to
write the whole thing in one programming language it's hard to test those modules independently especially when they can
be called around in that order you can't redeploy only part of this you
have to take the entire application and redeploy it all at once and because of that you can only move as fast as the
slowest person in your release cycle you have to synchronize your teams together find out when they are ready to release
and businesses with applications like this have a person called the release manager and that person says no to
everybody and then six months time they say ok we can release now and if you miss that train then you have to wait a
long time to get on the next one so we moved to micro-services in order to try
and solve these problems we are solving business problems here and we're using a technical means to do this we talk about
decomposing a monolith so we remove the dependencies we make it so things only
call each other in a straight line we define interfaces between these modules
so that you expose an API and you publish that as a contract so you know
people who call you are going to be able to call you regardless of what version of that software you've released and we
can update these independently as long as we keep to that API contract that's a
summary of the reasoning behind this ultimately it's about organizational
issues Jeff Bezos the founder of Amazon talks about two pizza teams you want a
team of people the small you can take two pizzas to feed them and that's the number of people that should work on any
individual service so we can get that velocity so they can deploy their software faster so we can decouple these
services from one another and then people can use whatever software makes
sense if there's part of their environment that makes sense to use in Erlang or Haskell or something we
can do this we don't need to tie everything to the same language you have to run on the JVM for example we're
decreasing how much a single person needs to know so they can care about the
things that matter to them and then they know the services that they have to interact with and hopefully something
that goes wrong somewhere else in that graph won't affect them so that's fantastic great we've decomposed down
monolith we're moving faster we can test easier we have these abstractions and we
can scale our services so the question is what what was the cost what have we
lost here inside our monolithic process we were the caller and we were the
destination so we knew that it was reliable because we were both ends running in that same process now that
call goes over a network the network may be insecure the latency on the network
might be high or it might change over time as the network is saturated you
have to worry about access control previously you were both the caller and the destination now we are having to
call someone and verify who we are all the way through and we used to debug
these processes by attaching a debugger to it and stepping through and looking at what happened now we have to say well
I'm not really sure what we do here how can we debug these things there are some
fixes that we can do here if we're worried about service a calling service B we can say try again maybe wait a
while longer if the first one fails and try again exponential back-off and then
we can add some headers to our calls to say isolators printf debugging basically
I started I called this other service I responded like where we got through and you can look through a trail of logs
from many different applications to figure this out then you can add security and authentication you can
build this into each application but because we have taken these modules and
possibly written them in different languages now we say I have to have a library that
works in Java and in Hesse gallon and Python and see so ultimately these micro
services that are designed to be small and micro anymore we have to worry about all of these things which are not
generating value for the business even once we have those things running when
we want to move to scale this is hard we used to give software out on disks to
one person at a time now we are serving software predominantly to millions of
concurrent users over the network so at the bottom of this we need to have some
sort of metrics we need to be able to say what is it that our application is doing and then we can monitor and alert
on those we want to be able to handle the encryption and identity both from
people calling outside and inside the network and then do things like rotation identity make sure that only services
that are allowed to call each other can do so we need to handle traffic
management we want to be able to do deployments of new services if we deploy
a new service we'd like to send a small portion of the traffic to it until we know it's successful and if a service
fails we might say we don't want to keep calling that service we want to gracefully degrade if we display a
webpage and it has a little widget that displays the weather if the weather widget is broken you can still display
the rest of the page ok you don't need to wait until that gets built so there are all of these things that we want to
do and so question is how does your startup or the DevOps organization and
your company deal with this so this is a start-up there's about 40 people I guess
working here at the time and ultimately when we think of what we've developed internally is - since we were that size
we talked about the culture of site reliability engineering or SRE
and we look at the way that we have developed services micro services or
larger scale so you've heard a lot the last couple of days about observability observability
starts with monitoring ultimately we can think of this is a food group pyramid or
Maslow's hierarchy pyramid and we can say you need monitoring before anything
else and what we've done is we've taken monitoring here and saying well let's break monitoring down what should you be
monitoring for micro-services so we call these four the golden signals these are
the things that you need to fundamentally know about traffic on your micro services environment traffic is
actually the first one so that's the the volume of requests or requests per second coming in to your service then
once you know that number you can see the number of areas knowing the number of areas alone isn't good enough because
if you have a hundred errors is that a lot if you have a hundred requests than 100 areas is a lot but if you have
millions upon millions of requests then that's okay that's a small percentage and that might be within your acceptable
boundaries so when we move further up again we're starting to say it's not so
much we need sleep and so on it's the nice to have things so we start looking at latency customers expect apps to be
fast so we need to make them fast and we
need to measure not just the average of requests but the slowest requests you
talk about the percentiles 99th percentile 99.9 the tail latency what is
it that the slowest people are seeing because ultimately that will dictate when things get slow throughout a chain
of course to microservices and then saturation will be something that matters custom to you and your workload
so it might be I'm overloading a CPU or I'm running out of memory or something that's custom to you but that is the
four signals that we recommend you monitor there's a great quote from an
early professor in computer science it says all problems can be solved by another level of indirection so how do
we monitor all of these things well we use a proxy server
traditionally people will think of a proxy service something like this you have a bunch of front-end services and a
bunch of back-end services and for these to call into that they call into this mid proxy that sits between them it's
able to do some authorizations and traffic routing or a load balancer for example and you have a proxy per certain
number so if you have 10 replicas you might have one proxy if you scale up you'll need to scale that as well so we
moved very quickly inside Google to what we call the sidecar model what we do
here is we take one proxy server a smaller one and we deploy it along with every back-end servers so we wrap these
things up and deploy them together which means we don't need to make any changes to the code we basically just intercept
the traffic that's going to hit that service through the proxy and now we can transparently collect that telemetry we
don't need to make any changes to the service we can use that as the way we do
security for these applications so it can terminate our TLS services and
because they're distributed we have one tied with every back-end we're getting rid of the single point of failure of
that single proxy server so we gain distributed load balancing you end up
with something like this if the front-end service wants to talk to the payment service it just calls out
it looks up the hostname payments and it connects out to that it is transparently intercepted by a proxy on the way out
and then at the payment service which can make decisions on whether or not to allow that traffic but it doesn't know
the front-end service doesn't know it just calls out to payments and it just works from its perspective that gives us
a lot of flexibility here so the traffic into our workloads being intercepted means we can do things like look at
quota is there a too many requests being made to the service for that particular user we can take authentication and
authorization decisions and move them out of your application so your developers don't need to keep rewriting
that same code and we can do the same thing on the way out so with all of the
same things there for metrics and logs and ensure that those services don't have to worry about security themselves they
just trust that the network does that for them we're able to also do things like dynamic routing so we've said
before we want to send a certain percentage of queries to a new service it doesn't know that it's happening at
the service level but we program the proxies to do that for us all of this is
done without having to make any changes to your application code so you start
off with a micro services architecture it's very simple it just looks something like this you describe in the standard
format perhaps of a communities deployment this is what I want to have and the cluster knows that it needs to
deploy these proxies when you deploy these workloads so it puts them in there like this again we're still talking in
the abstract here about the service what becomes a service mesh so then once
you've got all of these proxies running along with your backends and an ingress proxy so that you can work on traffic
from outside how does it know what to do well we already have a pattern for taking a lot of nodes and telling them
what it is to do and it's the born pattern what became the kubernetes pattern you have a control plane you can
figure that control plane and then it sends information out to a bunch of agents that control plane will then
program and maintain the proxies so it will inform them all of the state of the
services in your environment so everything that's deployed it tells each proxy server for this particular service
here are the endpoints so if it is doing round-robin load balancing for example it knows the things it needs to
round-robin - it doesn't need to call out to someone else to do that it needs to teach the proxy servers where to send
the metric information so when it has requests and it reports back the latency
so on what's back-tracing headers it sends that to a central place which is part of the control plan proxies enforce
policy so if you've enforced something about rate limiting or quotas or which users can access a particular service
you need to teach the proxies how to do that so we do that with the control plane also and then it also handles
certificate provisioning and rotation so that we can encrypt the traffic between all of these services
now hopefully by now this will sound very familiar to you all so first of all
if anyone's remembers Software Defined Networking anyone works at that layer we've basically just reinvented that but
the difference is is that we're doing it at layer 7 so we're able to make decisions based on application headers
we're able to say this traffic came in from a particular user whose name we know or a device of a particular type
and we're able to say here's a new service that we're testing which is going to work for Android users we're
not testing on iPhone users today so anyone who has a user agent that's his Android we can redirect their traffic
and that is only exposed to us in an HTTP header we don't know just by
looking at the network looking at the packet and the bytes what that is
and ultimately it should be familiar because we're a couple of years now into the concept of a service mesh so this is

great we'll work together and so that is where we got to sto now I'm not going to

install the control plane into your kubernetes environment you configure the cluster so that when you deploy a pod
spec to it it knows that it needs to deploy the sidecar proxy along with it the proxy server that we use is called

ride-sharing company in San Francisco for their micro services infrastructure so it is purpose-built for this kind of
thing we built the control plane to configure it and when you deploy that
into your environment you get all of that stuff before I'm pretty much for free so I want to talk

problems that needed a solution like this and what they found the first
company is called Descartes labs Descartes labs are a reasonably new

and they make machine learning models on earth data they get geospatial data they

can't built their environment with micro-services architecture they build
it on top of kubernetes running on GK and Tim told me a great story about the
early deployment he was out riding his mountain bike in the Sedona forest in

then kubernetes had said the workload that you asked for isn't running so did it recreated it and everything came back
up that's exactly what kubernetes is meant to do that's why we're all here because it solves that exact problem so
they've got an environment which is running great for them on kubernetes it's running a little bit too well it
turns out sometimes it's a bit slow sometimes a call to one of their
services takes longer than it should but they don't know why now they have
monitoring in their applications so they've deployed things like graph honor and in flux

spike and you know it has spiked but you don't know why the requests have just gone up is really hard to tell what it

environment they're now able to get metrics of the traffic between the services and find out who's calling who
and it turns out that they made these micro services that are very very useful
to do certain things in their environment they've scaled them for the size that they need for their production workloads

so it gave them an overview of the system and let them identify the areas
that were troubled now they sell that service out to customers and they want
to be able to offer an SLA so an SLA is basically a legal agreement that says if
the software wasn't available for at least 99.5% of the time then we give you
back some money in order to be able to do that they need a couple of other
things they actually need to set their objective and say well we need to try and hit this that's the 99.5 is what we
call a service level objective or an SLO and then in order to know whether or not
you hit that you need to indicate it you need a way of saying what was it that succeeded or failed and you need to
understand the baseline performance they say this is how things work in the general case so
that you know when things are out of whack if you want to be able to offer a
service that is this reliable you need to make sure all the services you depend on are that reliable or more and you

alerting on this you can say I'm trending downwards I know that I've ninety nine point five percent is seven
